channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu's next moves
item.description: Since the Gaza ceasefire began, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has received a boost from President Trump, and is gearing up to run for reelection.
item.content:encoded: Since the Gaza ceasefire began, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has received a boost from President Trump, and is gearing up to run for reelection.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Part of the U.S. strategy in 20 years of war in Afghanistan? Weakening poppies
item.description: In an exclusive Washington Post story, reporter Warren Strobel describes a CIA operation in Afghanistan over the course of about a decade. The goal was to degrade the country's opium crop.
item.content:encoded: In an exclusive Washington Post story, reporter Warren Strobel describes a CIA operation in Afghanistan over the course of about a decade. The goal was to degrade the country's opium crop.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Ofman

item.title: For clues on how to evade cancer, some scientists look to the bowhead whale
item.description: Where might we look for inspiration for new cancer therapies? Some researchers say the bowhead whale may offer clues.
item.content:encoded: Where might we look for inspiration for new cancer therapies? Some researchers say the bowhead whale may offer clues.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Superfans turn out for U.S. Olympic Curling Team trials
item.description: Ahead of the Winter Olympics in Milan in February, curling superfans turn out in Sioux Falls, S.D., for trials to determine which U.S. team will compete in "chess on ice" against the world.
item.content:encoded: Ahead of the Winter Olympics in Milan in February, curling superfans turn out in Sioux Falls, S.D., for trials to determine which U.S. team will compete in "chess on ice" against the world.
item.dc:creator: Pien Huang

item.title: Clinics that provide abortion in Maine face an onslaught
item.description: Abortion is supported by three out of four Mainers, but a popular network of clinics that provides it alongside primary care is being shut out of Medicaid by the Trump administration.
item.content:encoded: Abortion is supported by three out of four Mainers, but a popular network of clinics that provides it alongside primary care is being shut out of Medicaid by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Selena Simmons-Duffin

item.title: Comet 3I/Atlas doesn't need to be 'alien' to deserve a closer look, scientists say
item.description: There's a new celebrity in town and it's... a comet. Much of the attention has to do with an astrophysicist's grandiose suggestions that 3I/ATLAS could contain alien life. Other scientists disagree.
item.content:encoded: There's a new celebrity in town and it's... a comet. Much of the attention has to do with an astrophysicist's grandiose suggestions that 3I/ATLAS could contain alien life. Other scientists disagree.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Study finds human ancestors made tools continuously for 300,000 years
item.description: Ailsa Chang speaks with David Braun, an archeologist, about his team's discovery of a site in Kenya that suggests human ancestors built tools continuously much earlier than previously thought.
item.content:encoded: Ailsa Chang speaks with David Braun, an archeologist, about his team's discovery of a site in Kenya that suggests human ancestors built tools continuously much earlier than previously thought.
item.dc:creator: Henry Larson

item.title: DOJ records show hundreds of immigrants arrested in Chicago had no criminal histories
item.description: DOJ records show that more than 600 arrests in Chicago's recent immigration enforcement operation may have violated a federal consent decree. And of those arrested, fewer than 3% had criminal records.
item.content:encoded: DOJ records show that more than 600 arrests in Chicago's recent immigration enforcement operation may have violated a federal consent decree. And of those arrested, fewer than 3% had criminal records.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: 'Gleaners' collect crops for hungry Americans
item.description: When farm crops are harvested, there is often food left in the fields. That's where gleaners come in — gathering lettuce, potatoes and other crops that are still good and giving them to needy people.
item.content:encoded: When farm crops are harvested, there is often food left in the fields. That's where gleaners come in — gathering lettuce, potatoes and other crops that are still good and giving them to needy people.
item.dc:creator: Jill Kaufman

item.title: These San Antonio grandmas show cultural pride and 'stay young' by dancing folklórico
item.description: A dozen Latina grandmothers ages 73 to 86 formed a folklórico dance group in San Antonio known as Las Abuelitas De Oro, with a goal of sharing their cultural heritage with newer generations.
item.content:encoded: A dozen Latina grandmothers ages 73 to 86 formed a folklórico dance group in San Antonio known as Las Abuelitas De Oro, with a goal of sharing their cultural heritage with newer generations.
item.dc:creator: Ivanna Bass Caldera
